name: Shitheads!
description:
Three Shitheads  - Same, Old and Shit.

Original Criminal Chalkist piece, as a three piece set.

Politricks never smelt better.

name: WAKE ME UP original
description:
Wake me up when the revolution begins... Where does the revolution come from?

Originally Created for the street and painted in the street of Montpelier, Bristol, UK. Bristol is the home of UK street art and also is the home of revolution. Remember the revolution starts in the mind!

Criminal Chalkist painted this piece for a Restaurant in Bristol as part of an array of local Bristol artists. It is currently on display at BYZANTIUM Restaurant in Bristol. 

Measuring around 1.5m wide and 1m tall, this piece is made to make a statement and not only is it a call to Criminal Chalkists fellow man and women, but also as a self reflective piece on just where the revolution begins for Criminal Chalkist. 

Handpainted over the space of 6 days, this piece is one of CRIMINAL CHALKISTS most strong and passionate messages. 

Painted on wood, Using Acrylic paint.

name: LOVE YOU MUM print
description:
A4 CRIMINAL CHALKIST PRINT

Ideal for mothers day, or in fact any day if you love your mum.

Prints - Limited edition, run of 50, Each signed and numbered.

name: LOVE YOU MUM original spray
description:
A3 HANDPAINTED CRIMINAL CHALKIST DESIGN

Ideal for mothers day, or in fact any day if you love your mum.

these aren't prints, but each one painted individually. If you would like to choose the colours that are not listed here, then please get in contact via criminal chalkist facebook.

Handpainted. Each signed..

name: have a heart
description:
Plaster of paris on canvas piece. Pinks and purples. 

Finished with spray can. Original Criminal Chalkist piece - much love from BRISTOL

name: Wake me up!
description:
A new print from Criminal Chalkist based on his recent street piece of the same name.

Still sleeping? 

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=510218349021706&set=a.212746425435568.53445.211589938884550&type=1&theater

And even better, each one comes signed  - A4 PRINT

name: Free Shop
description:
In 2011, the freeshop and emporium buildings were evicted, and the dream of having a community shop based on the ethos od 'people before profit' looked like it was over. a few days after the eviction, the building was reoccupied, albeit with Sitex plastered over the front of it - (metal sheets to prevent reaccess) 

The free shop needed to have some colour splashed over it. 

Leaving the sitex on, Criminal Chalkist and friends from London and Italy respectively painted this. 

So whatever the future holds for the freeshop, the idea behind it and the possible future it has can always remain in memory with this lovingly made print and equally loving street piece.

A limited run of 35 prints will be available of this. Each print signed and individually numbered.

name: BREATHE (4 out of 5 left)
description:
A new piece up from Criminal Chalkist. 

Painted with acrylics, cans and stencil, Criminal Chalkist takes his painting back to his roots with this one. Combining a wide array of brush strokes, to make this loving warm piece of work.

This is 1 out of 5 original handmade designs on canvas. Each one will differ on the background colours and brushstrokes.

Signed by artist and individually numbered. 

(also limited edition run of prints available - from print run of 25. Please contact on Facebook or by email: paulsaville2012@gmail.com -  for more information on these)

name: Criminal Chalkist: 'Chalking about a Revolution' BOOK
description:
Coming Soon!

Criminal Chalkist writes about Chalk, the criminal justice system, revolution (both personal & political) getting arrested for writing in chalk, chalk art and much more: In the new book entitled 'chalking about a revolution'

name: SAME OLD SHIT
description:
Three piece canvas set, painted and signed by Criminal Chalkist: £90.00

In three colours: Red, Yellow, Blue - To represent the three main political parties in the UK.

Vote Blue, Vote Red, Vote yellow - It doesn't matter which one you choose - It's the same old shit!

Criminal Chalkist has designed these canvases with democracy in mind - and the lacking representation of us everyday people on the street.

name: Sometimes in life it doesn't matter which way you go... PRINT
description:
Another Criminal Chalkist piece in which there was very little planning to it. 

Chalked on the street in 2010, This piece tried to advise people on the best way to go - practically speaking. Going left would take people further into the park, going right would take you to the shopping centre.

This piece also serves as Political commentary. Interestingly, a few people went right after seeing the message. Most went left. One smart child decided to cycle his bike right through the centre, following his heart and his dreams.

name: We are all mad here PRINT
description:
This image is iconic in the history of the Criminal Chalkist. Sketched out on the streets of Bristol, in the same place as he was arrested just weeks previous, this was drawn out as part of a wider social commentary on how just crazy things have got in the UK. 

Whilst we are bombarded by a media that tells us that we live in a dangerous world, the police decided to arrest someone drawing in chalk that would wash away just as quickly as it was drawn. 

this time, the police left Criminal Chalkist alone and this was the result: "We are all mad here"

Interestingly, Criminal Chalkist chalked this on a friday evening and finished it by the time the sun was going down. By Saturday morning, someone had vomited all over it. Alls fair in the love and war!

name: Purple Haze PRINT
description:
Criminal chalkist painted the purple faced girl on the streets of Bristol in 2011.

The idea behind the piece was that just like Purple Haze, the girls hair is blowing in the wind. Using Blues and Purples, This piece was later sent to Criminal Chalkists Printers with this quote:

"Art enables us to find ourselves and lose ourselves at the same time." - Thomas Merton

and for Criminal Chalkist - It really has.

name: The Same but different.
description:
Arriving in a two part canvas, Criminal Chalkist created this piece in 2012. 

Criminal Chalkist says: "Although I believe that we are all unique, each with our own likes, dislikes and characteristics, we are fundamentally the same, through our needs for: Love, warmth, Shelter, food and water. Lets remember what brings us together rather than what separates us shall we?"

One other version of this canvas was displayed in the 'deep end' exhibition which took place in an abandoned swimming pool in Bristol in the spring of 2012. This was sold to a private collector who went along to the exhibition and like the piece so much, tracked down Criminal Chalkist and bought the set from him directly.

http://www.bristol247.com/2012/05/09/dive-into-the-deep-end-to-breathe-life-into-communities-86322/

The exhibition featured work from artists such as Liz Buckfield, Filthy Luker, FLX, Deadposh, Deams, Criminal Chalkist among others.

name: Rob a shop go to jail, rob a nation get a bonus! PRINT
description:
The first collaboration project between Criminal Chalkist and No Comment.

During the 3 days of rioting in London that took place in 2011, the media spoke often about how the looters had attacked shops, showing scenes of burning, looting and smashed windows.

The damage done by the Banking Heist of 2009 was not shown however. 

Criminal Chalkist & No Comment paint the Irony of it all, in typical Comical style.

Individually signed by CrimCEE

name: V is for Vagina PRINT
description:
Exploring the idea of women and revolution literally 'gave birth' to this piece.

Awareness, education, and life's struggles have led women to shed their inhibitions. Great women leaders, artists, scientists and women everywhere inspired Criminal Chalkist to create this.

V is for Vagina

name: Heres Johnny!
description:
Lovingly splattered over a canvas, this piece was created in the Summer of 2012. The creepy girl was lifted from a biscuit advert from the 1940's. 

Criminal Chalkist Original piece - on square canvas. Only 5 of these were made.

name: Is that a Banksy? PRINT
description:
In 2011, It seemed to Criminal Chalkist and his friend No Comment that most if not all Stencil art was being referred to as 'a Banksy'

the boys decided to paint this piece in the street and watch from across the road, in order to see what peoples reaction would be to it. 

the reaction was extraordinary. whilst it pissed down with rain, people stopped underneath their English umbrellas and looked at the piece for a while. Some took photos. Some people stopped to have a chat with other people and said: "Yes, I know, BUT IS IT A BANKSY?"

Individually signed and numbered - Limited release from a print run of 50.

name: Consume or die? PRINT
description:
Pacmans mission in life is to consume all the 'dots' on the map. If Pacman stops, the game stops. But what happens when Pacman has eaten all of the resources?

This piece undertaken by Criminal Chalkist attempts to explain the desperation in the west in many of our lives. 

This is available in print format, either in A4 or A3 format. This is also a limited edition print, with 25 of each format available. Get in touch :)

name: Chalk by Criminal Chalkist
description:
Ever fancied taking to the streets and making them a little more colourful? Now you can. These are the best chalks on the market and there is 40 of the beauties in the pack. They are chunky, easy to use and really are colourful colours! (orange, yellow, purple, green, white, red, brown, blue)

Each pack you order will come signed by CriminalChalkist as well, so you will be getting your hands on something that could be worth some money in the future. 

but you'll probably be more tempted to taking them out on the street and creating something wonderful yourself. Bulk orders also welcome, but please get in touch first.

name: No Tesco In Stokes Croft!
description:
During a (in total) 15 month campaign to stop Tesco building what would their 34th store in Bristol, many tactics were used, which saw the building occupied by squatters, petitions, various art pieces were designed, fundraisers, music and dance.

During the build up to one of the protests which was to happen outside the proposed building for Tesco, Criminal chalkist made 50 handmade signs for everyone who attended the protest. He also designed and made this as a special one off memoribilia piece. 

There is only one of these and it won't be made again.

Signed by the original artist.

name: Toilet Information!
description:
From Street to Canvas. Criminal Chalkist designed this piece to go on the street, toilet wall or even on your lounge wall.

A consistent reminder that although the media may try to feed us information through the medium of newspapers, sometimes more information can be sought by looking at a toilet wall - Especially in Bristol!

Colours may vary. If you have a colour preference, please let us know!

name: 100 metre dash! PRINT - Signed and individually numbered.
description:
*HURRY! last 4 of the original print run of 50 left! limited edition!*

A limited edition run of 50 prints which were made by Criminal Chalkist and his friend No Comment for the Olympics held in 2012 in the UK.

Painted originally on the street back in July 2011, in Stokes Croft, Bristol UK.

The piece went global during the olympic period alongside a whole host of other artists including Banksy, Edgar Amroyan & CodeFC.

More information here: http://thedifferentbrain.com/2012/07/olympic-street-art/


the piece was also featured in the LA Times: http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jul/23/entertainment/la-et-cm-olympics-street-art-20120723
  
Each Print is signed and numbered, so once they have gone: they have gone!

Get your chalk olympics now! a4 print.
